title: Fasting Experiment
content: Why a one-week fast was conducted and the rationale for front- and back-ending it with a week-long ketogenic diet. What a typical diet, exercise, sleep, stress management, and supplementation looks like. What labs (e.g., glucose, ketones, lipids, inflammation and oxidation markers, thyroid, sex hormones) were checked for the experiment. The results after one week on a ketogenic diet. The results after a week on a water-only fast. The results after a week on a ketogenic diet following a week of fasting. The top 6 surprises from the fasting experiment. Different fasting-mimicking diet (FMD) protocols. What is the optimal protocol, frequency, and duration for fasting? How to break a fast without GI distress? Am I breaking the fast if…?

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting. Translating complex scientific topics into actionable insights.

title: Impact of stress on health
content: The impact of stress on our physical and emotional health.

title: Optimizing brain health
content: Optimizing brain health: Alzheimer's disease risk factors, APOE, prevention strategies, and more.

title: Training principles for longevity
content: Training principles for longevity.

title: Preventing Cardiovascular Disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Pros and Cons of GLP-1 Weight Loss Drugs and Metformin
content: Discussion on the pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Overcoming Trauma and Finding Inner Peace
content: Discussion on overcoming trauma, finding inner peace, and living a meaningful and fulfilling life.

title: The History of the Cell, Cell Therapy, and Gene Therapy
content: Discussion on the history of the cell, cell therapy, gene therapy, and more.

title: Alzheimer's Disease and Lifestyle Factors
content: Discussion on Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more.

title: Cancer Risk and Lifestyle Factors
content: Discussion on cancer risk including the relationship between cancer and exercise as well as the link between alcohol consumption and cancer.

title: Exercise and Protein Consumption
content: Discussion on the new focus on exercise and protein consumption as well as how the perspective has shifted as it pertains to fasting and time-restricted feeding.

title: Autophagy and Fasting
content: Discussion on autophagy and the most effective way known to induce autophagy is to completely fast. Other things like exercise and rapamycin are also known to induce autophagy.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Fasting
content: Discussion on the ketogenic diet and its role in fasting. Going into a fast from a high-carbohydrate state is more painful. It’s more of an abrupt shift from glucose metabolism to ramping up the process of making ketones, which is critical in starvation.

title: Exercise Routine
content: M/W/F lift—each day focuses on one heavy hip-hinge exercise and one pulling exercises; plus ancillary movements (total time about 90 min). Other 4 days, usually cycling (Wahoo and Peloton), typically 45-75 min.

title: Sleep Pattern
content: 7-7.5 hours of actual sleep time. Low latency times and infrequent wakeups. Good sleep score (Oura ring). Historically, light on the heavy (stage 3-4) and heavy on the light (stage 1-2) (via Oura ring measurement).

title: Stress Management
content: Higher than average stress. Consistent routine of mindfulness/Vipassana meditation.

title: Supplements & Medications
content: Supplements (OTC) include Vitamin D, Methylfolate, Methyl B12, Lithium, EPA/DHA, Selenium, Baby aspirin, NAC, Curcumin, Mg oxide, Slo-Mg. Medications (Prescription) include Metformin, Atorvastatin, Ezetimibe. No change in any supplement or medication during the experiment other than the addition of bouillon and doubling the dosage of magnesium.

title: Body Composition Changes
content: Ideally would have gotten DEXA scans in addition to blood tests. Instead, took four selfies to assess observable lean tissue and fat mass changes.

title: Diet
content: Breakfast: Skipping breakfast or had a light breakfast. Typically coffee with MCT powder. Lunch: Macadamia nuts, Avocado, Olives. Dinner: Salad, Modest protein.

title: Health Results
content: Triglycerides (TGs) went up, LDL-P went way up, Small LDL (sLDL) went to 800, Uric acid went up, Homocysteine was high, Free T3 (fT3) went down, T4 (thyroxine) went up, fT3/rT3 ratio tanked, Body wanting to slow the metabolism down, Lost around 4 lbs from baseline, IGF-1 did not drop.

title: Fasting Experiment Surprises
content: Relatively trivial weight loss, Enormous improvement in sleep, A feeling of calmness and presentness, The most bizarre paradox of physical performance, Deterioration of peripheral thyroid function, Complete elimination of a chronic pain in right wrist and near-complete elimination of pain in left elbow.

title: Different Fasting Protocols
content: Has done different variations of an FMD. The Prolon FMD is relatively higher in carbohydrate than a KD. One variation is a KD version of an FMD, Another variation is a TRF-FMD: one meal a day of rice and salad, typically lower in protein than Prolon.

title: Optimal Protocol for Fasting
content: An important tenet to longevity is exposure to nutrient cycling (autophagy and mTOR up and down). Frequency of the fast might be a function of the damage you do off the fast. Frequency of the fast might be a function of your metabolic health.

title: Breaking the Fast
content: When you’ve been fasting, the stomach is decompressed. You can get hiccups if you add too much volume back to your stomach.
